intro.p: It's finals week in the tutoring center, and {{stu}} brings you an exam packet and a question.
"This question wants me to 'fill in the missing value'," {{pn}} say{{suf}}. "And I did that! But my roommate told me it's wrong."
{{stu}} has only brought {{ppn}} notebook so you can't see the original question, only the table of data {{pn}} wrote down:

content.p: "Aha!" you say. "I think I found the missing value you filled in: the one that doesn't fit the pattern."
Which one of the five values of f(x) does not match the pattern of the other four?
Explain in 2-3 sentences why it doesn't match. What do you think {{stu}}'s reasoning was, and what similar problem did {{stu}} correctly solve with this missing value?

outtro.p: The data point ( {{wrongx}} , {{wrongy}} ) does not math the pattern of the others. {{stu}}'s value would have been correct if the other four data points followed a linear relationship. (Convince yourself that they do not!)

content.p: "I still don't believe you," {{stu}} says. "My roommate is {{major}} major, {{pn}} didn't even have to take college algebra."
"Fine," you say. "Don't believe me: believe the data. Look what happens every time x increases by 1."
What happens in this data every time x increases by 1, that would convince {{stu}} of the pattern in the (correct) four data points? Explain.

outtro.p: Each time that x increases by 1 in the correct data points, the value of f(x) {{changes}} by a factor of (is multiplied by) {{b}}.

content.p: "Wait, so this is an exponential function?" {{stu}} says skeptically. "Does that mean it's some kind of e-to-the-x formula?"
"Yes and no," you say equivocally. "Since we know what happens every time x increases by 1, we can find a simpler formula that matches this data without using the number e."
Determine a formula for f(x) that fits this data using its base and intercept. Then, use the formula to show {{stu}} what the correct value of the missing f(x) should have been.

outtro.p: A formula for this function is f(x) = {{f}}. Using this formula, we should have f(\, {{wrongx}}\, ) = {{righty}}.
